text: I can’t believe what you did. After everything we’ve been through, I never thought you’d go behind my back like that. The lies, the manipulation—it’s like I never knew you. I trusted you with parts of me I don’t share with anyone. And you used them against me. I’m furious. It’s not just betrayal—it’s a complete gut punch. I’m so angry I could scream.

Today, I watched another young Black man get treated like a criminal for doing nothing. Just standing there. The police didn’t hesitate to intimidate him, hand on the holster, voice full of assumption. And everyone just kept walking. I’m so tired of seeing this. I’m so tired of the system pretending it’s neutral. I’m enraged. How many times do we have to scream to be heard?

Some idiot cut me off and nearly sideswiped my car. No signal, no glance—just swerved like he owned the road. I slammed the brakes, heart racing, hands white-knuckled on the wheel. I shouted out of pure rage. The nerve of some people. It wasn’t just dangerous—it was disrespectful. I’m still boiling thinking about it.

I tried to open up. I really did. And you laughed it off like I was being “too sensitive.” That stung more than anything I was trying to talk about. I felt invisible. Invalidated. Angry. Why even ask how I’m feeling if you’re going to toss it aside like trash? I deserve to be heard.

I said no. I made it clear. And still, you pushed. You touched without permission. You kept asking after I said I was done. That’s not persistence—it’s a violation. I’m furious. I deserve to feel safe in my space, and you stole that. This anger sits deep in my chest like fire.

The bathroom was a disaster. Mold in the sink, used tissues everywhere, and that smell… it hit me like a wall. I nearly gagged. How can anyone live like that? I felt sick just standing in there. I wanted to scrub my skin clean for hours after.

I saw a video today of a dog being abused. It turned my stomach. The way that man laughed while hurting an innocent animal made me feel physically ill. It’s not just wrong—it’s vile. How can someone be so heartless? I felt disgusted by the world, honestly.

Something rotting in the back of the fridge hit me like a slap to the face. It was this wet, sour, almost metallic stench that stuck in my nose for hours. I couldn’t breathe without gagging. Even after cleaning it out, the memory of that smell haunted me.

She lied. Repeatedly. And with a straight face. I found out she’d been taking credit for my work for months. My stomach dropped. The fakeness, the manipulation—it makes my skin crawl. I feel dirty just having trusted her.

I bit into what I thought was a fresh sandwich, but one bite in and the meat was slimy and sour. I spit it out immediately. My throat clenched, my stomach turned, and I couldn’t shake the taste. I felt gross for hours after. Just thinking about it makes me nauseous again.

The car swerved toward me out of nowhere. I slammed the brakes, heart pounding like a drum, hands shaking. For a moment, I thought, this is it. That second stretched forever. Even after it passed, the fear stayed. I could’ve died. It doesn’t feel real.

The spotlight hit me, and suddenly, I couldn’t breathe. My hands were sweating, heart thudding in my ears. The words I practiced vanished from my brain. Every pair of eyes felt like judgment. I wanted to run. The fear was paralyzing.

I’m leaving everything I know behind. New city. No safety net. What if I fail? What if I regret it? The fear creeps in at night, whispering worst-case scenarios. I want to believe in this new chapter, but the unknown is terrifying.

I heard something outside. A creak, maybe a knock. Every shadow looked alive. The darkness swallowed everything familiar, and I felt so small. My imagination ran wild, and fear gripped me like a vise. I barely slept.

She didn’t answer her phone. It had been hours. My mind spiraled—accidents, emergencies, the worst. I kept picturing her hurt. That fear, the kind that steals your breath—it was unbearable. I don’t want to lose her.

I opened the door, and there she was—smiling, arms wide. I screamed and hugged her so tight. I hadn’t seen her in months, and it felt like the sun burst inside my chest. Everything felt lighter, warmer. Pure joy.

I did it. After years of work, setbacks, and doubt—I finally crossed the finish line. My diploma in hand, tears in my eyes. I felt proud, relieved, happy. This is what I worked for. This is what it feels like to win.

Today was one of those perfect days. Sun warming my skin, a breeze in the trees. I walked through the park with no rush. Birds singing, people smiling. I felt at peace. Just...happy to be alive in that moment.

Laughter echoed through the room, cake was passed around, and everyone was glowing with joy. We toasted, danced, and made memories I’ll treasure forever. Being surrounded by love like that—it filled me with deep happiness.

I stood in front of that painting and felt something shift inside me. The colors, the story—it spoke to a part of me I didn’t know needed to be heard. It was breathtaking. For a few minutes, I forgot everything but that feeling of awe and joy.

I held her little paw as she took her last breath. My heart broke. She was more than a pet—she was family. Every corner of the house feels empty without her. I miss her terribly. I keep looking for her, and she's not there.
We tried. God, we really tried. But in the end, we walked away. And now everything feels hollow. I miss the way we laughed. I miss the comfort. But we couldn’t hold on anymore. It hurts so much.

I sat in a crowded room and felt completely invisible. Everyone else had someone. I had no one. It’s a quiet sadness—the kind that creeps in when you realize how disconnected you feel from the world. I just want to be seen.

I hesitated—and the moment passed. The job went to someone else. I keep replaying it, wondering what could’ve been if I’d just taken the leap. The regret sits heavy. That chance won’t come again, and it hurts.

I saw the footage of refugees today—children crying, people sleeping on streets, families torn apart. My heart broke. I cried. It feels like the world is unraveling, and I can’t fix it. That helplessness—it’s so heavy.

I opened my email expecting a rejection—and there it was: “Congratulations.” I blinked, reread it five times. I got the scholarship. I screamed. Happy tears, shaky hands. I still can’t believe it. I’m over the moon.
I turned the corner, and there they were. We locked eyes—and just knew. Years melted away in an instant. We hugged like we’d never let go. Life gave us a beautiful surprise today.
I was ready for a boring day, and suddenly—bam! Road trip! No planning, just vibes. It was chaotic, unfiltered joy. I didn’t expect it, but it turned into one of the best days I’ve had in ages.
We were walking by the beach when the sky exploded into color—an aurora, right there. We stood in silence, stunned. It felt unreal, like nature was putting on a show just for us. Pure wonder.
She told me the truth today—and I didn’t see it coming. My jaw dropped. A part of me was hurt, but mostly, I was stunned. I never expected that from her. It changes everything.
